The food was unspectacular, but I was so hungry that it tasted like a feast. Swirling the goblet of mead, I watched the golden liquid lap around like a tiny ocean.

After the repast, I pounded the lumpy, musty-smelling bed with my fists, bidding it to be more welcome to my weary body. My armor, I removed, though my chest and leg plates stood nearby. My dagger, as always, remained strapped securely to my right ankle with a leather bond. I hit the pillow, my face covered by my long, raven hair as I lay wary on my back. Not much sleep would be had tonight.

I had seen the lustful stares of several males, all mercenaries, as I'd made my way up to the barkeep's station. It has always been difficult being a female in this line of work, but since I am able to fight, slash, dismember and escape unscathed, I feel I should be treated as they are. Perhaps not in this century.

The assignment I would be getting tomorrow-would it take me on as far a trip as I'd just returned from? Would I find the terms to be reasonable? What about the danger? I tossed restlessly upon the lumpy mattress and beat the pillow one last time before getting a few hours' spotty sleep.

I awoke, as I always do, with my right hand wrapped around the handle of my dagger. The sunlight was spotty, choking its way through thick clouds which promised rain. I jumped up, washed quickly with the tepid water in my bedside bucket, and strapped on my armor. This would be a day to remember.

Being an half-elf wasn't so bad....save for the hatred, rejection, and hassle i got from people.
oh well.

I heard footsteps outside my door. Brief whispers...then silence.
I redied my scimitar.
the door was kicked open and three large bodied men entered my room.
"Hey freak, you don't belong here...among the normal people."

I held my tongue. Last thing i needed ...or wanted....was a fight.
The leader approached me.
"you hear me? you should..your ears are large enough...."
He reached down to grab my collar.

My shade reflexes took effect and i whirled behind him.
I grabbed his arm and twisted it behind him...immobilizing him completely.
the other two started towards me.

Using my other arm, i unsheathed my blade and pointed it at them.
" I'm not in the mood for games....you want a fight? I can give you one...."
they stared at each other....then rushed out the door.

Sighing, i pushed the man away...spiraling him to the floor.
"I suggest you get out."
The bulky man slowly managed to stand.

"ya freak of nature....."
with that, he exited my room.
i sighed.

i had hoped this town would be easier than most i had visited in the past.....didn't look to promising so far.
Only time will tell.

they obviously are looking for trouble.

he only nods and walks away.

he hold up your coin purse.

You look at the 15 men charging towards you.
Cracking a small smile, you run at them.

The first man falls from a hit to the jaw...second goes down soon after.

two more...

There are five of them, to buy them all an ale will cost 5gp's.

Do you want to buy them all a drink?
15411.title: Trouble brewing?

154111.content:
So they all sit down at a table and drink, which loosens their defenses, (as you planned) and boast about business and exploits in the local areas.

You listen with aloof interest, only speaking enough to keep the conversation going and drinking only enough of your own ale to avoid questions.

Finally, one of the men brags about a cushy job he has with a local, wealthy merchant. Room, board and ale are generously included as well as decent pay. The job sounds simple, just guard the guy's caravans for short trips to the towns in the nearby area and when there's no trips, then help keep the estate secure. Can't get much more easy than that. However, it seems that this merchant guy demands that anyone he hires promises at least six months of service up front.

Usually, someone like you would never consider such a commitment. Much better to be able to check it out and have the freedom to cut and run whenever you need to.

So, do you wait for the next job they mention in hopes of more flexibility? Or do you entertain the idea and ask more information on this merchant guy?
154111.title: The local Bloodline

choices: Offer to go with the second guy to check it out
Just keep the address in mind, in case ...
1541111.content:
"Well, the merchant is an old geezer with lots of family baggage. Seems he's crabby, but it hardly matters since he doesn't deal directly with the caravans. His oldest son runs all the trips and he's doesn't really seem to give a darn as long as the merchandise gets delivered on time.

"Gotta daughter too," the man added with a wink. "She's one babe I'd like to get to know better."

The others in the group laughed, but when they pressed for details, the man sighed and shrugged. "The old geezer keeps a close eye on her. She never leaves the estate and the other son is always hangin' around her. He always wears a sword, but I doubt the brat can actually use it. Think the old man orders the jerk to keep an eye on her."

One of the other guys grins. "Probably all for show. Stuff like that usually means the girl's eager for a little freedom - maybe the old man knows she's lonely. Sounds like an interesting challenge, lot more profitable and interesting than my last job. Who do I gotta talk to to get in?"

The man gives an address.
1541111.title: Added potential or  just complications?

choices: "We're looking for work and heard you were hiring."
Whip out your knife and demand, "Hand over those coins and no one gets hurt.
15411111.content:
You decide that the profit and luxuries of the job might outweigh the contract issue and certainly beats the option of being dime-a-dozen meat fodder for the warring factions. It's worth looking into anyway.

With that decided, you take your meal in your room. You eat what you can stomach and shove the hard-roll in your stuff for the morning.

In the morning you wait in the common room for the other guy, but several hours pass and it's approaching noon before he stumbles into sight, clutching his head and muttering curses.

Rolling your eyes, you confront the guy, remind him of the job offer, and help him stagger out of the inn.

By the time you track down the address it's almost evening, but your companion has recovered from his hang-over and after washing his face at a nearby well, he's presentable. However, hunger is gnawing at you and after hours of dragging the guy around, you've decided that you don't like him. When he finally gets around to giving you his name, it only confirms your conclusions – Taz sounds more like a street urchin or cut-purse and not a respectable mercenary.

The estate is at the very edge of Hewor and looks like an old military garrison with rotting timbers and crumbling brick mortar that someone had tried to convert into sprawling nobleman's home, but gave up in the middle of the process. Moss and dark ivy tendrils covered sections of the outer wall allowing multiple areas for would-be intruders to hide and considering the crumbling gaps you can see, you wouldn't be surprised if some of the ivy covered holes big enough for such an intruder to slip through.

When you inquire about the job at the guard house, you are led through a servants' entrance in the back of the main house and into a sparse library where an old gray-haired human sits at a large desk scribbling on parchment and counting silver coins.

He peers up at you with squinting gray-blue eyes. "What do you want?"
15411111.title: The Merchant's Home

choices: Ask questions and insist on reading the contract yourself.
154111111.content:
The merchant eyes you up and down, dubiously and then scowls at Taz. "I assume you're talking about caravan guards." He shifts through the parchments and pulls out a sheet about a hand's length long and wide, then slaps it down on the desk in front of you. "This is a six month contract that you will follow my rules and provide the list of services. Follow it and room, food, suitable clothing, drink and 10 gold coins a day will be paid to you. Break this contract and I'll have you thrown into jail for at least a year. Your duties are to guard any caravan I assign you to, particularly protecting the merchandise as well as my people and any family members traveling with you. While traveling with a caravan, you are never to leave site of it, drink more than one pint of ale a day, give any information to other travelers not with the caravan or allow any strangers – particularly females – near the wagons after sunset. While not with a caravan, you are to protect my possessions, my family and my land. You are not to enter the main house without an invitation. You are never to enter the private living quarters of any member of my family or ever threaten them with a drawn weapon – drunk or sober. Any guest you bring on to the estate, you are responsible for them knowing and following the same rules. If you ever steal, endanger – directly or indirectly – my family or servants, or give information about my person, business or household to any person other than my family and I alone, then you will be held in breach of contract."

The man then holds out a stick of charcoal to you.

You eye him, then the paper.

The merchant rolls his eyes with a groan. "I assume that you can write at least your name."

Taz shrugs. "I'm in," he declares as he takes the offered charcoal and scribbles a "TZ" on the parchment beneath the tight ink writing that filled most of the pale surface.
154111111.title: The Job, the rules & the Contract

choices: You agreed to it, so you eat quickly and get ready to go
Drag your feet, decide to pass this time up and go exploring
1541111111.content:
You scratch your name into the parchment and are hustled out of the house the same way you came then directed to one of the out-buildings. It probably used to be the barracks.

You are given new clothes that look sturdy, decent sewing job and reserve colors of gray and brown that certainly won't attract attention. You are assigned a straw mattress, a clothes chest, a shared wash-stand and a few hooks on the wall for you to store your cloak and weapons. The place reeks of sweat and ale, with the hint of cheap female perfume. Most of the other men are straight human and sound half-drunk already so you keep to yourself until you can get the measure of where you stand.

Taz, on the other hand, has no such reserves and is happily drunk and singing bawdy tavern songs in no time.

After a hearty meal that tastes far better than what you had last night and one mug of ale, you feel more comfortable with your decision. The others are friendly and accept your half-blood status without comment.

Although it's not your style to sleep near so many strangers in a enclosed building, nothing particular happens in the night and you manage a good night's rest – which is good, since at dawn you and Taz are selected as two of the twenty guards leaving with a caravan that afternoon.

You're disappointed at the short notice and would prefer some time to explore your new home.
1541111111.title: Getting Settled in

choices: Take the drink (&whatever else you can) & enjoy the job
my word=my bond! stick to the rules set by the contract
15411111111.content:
The trip out covered an uneventful two days.

The guy from the bar was right that the elder son of the merchant, a thin man in his late twenties called Gallino, seemed pretty relaxed about the rules. He in no way concerned himself with recording the number of drinks the men shared at night, although he would threaten anyone who looked obviously drunk, especially if they caused any problems or noise.

However, on the return trip and once Gallino had dealt with selling or trading the merchandise at the other town, the mood of the camp completely changed. The first night on the return trip, the merchant's son ordered three large barrels of ale unloaded from the wagon and encouraged the guards to indulge themselves. Wasn't long past sunset when you noted thinly-clad women doling out drinks and flirting with the guards. No women were allowed as part of the caravan so they obviously had been invited to join in the fun, although most of them didn't seem to be catering to a paying customer, but rather the group in large. It certainly wasn't what the old geezer's rules had suggested.

After your first mug of ale, one of the women – a sexy blond, with high cheeks and green eyes – offers you another.

What do you do?
15411111111.title: The Caravan

choices: Return to the Inn to look for accomplices interested in a rich prize?
Such betray is too low for you.  Your job is to protect against such!
154111111111.content:
True, you quickly lost count of the drinks you accepted from the blond, but it really paid off because she stayed at your side the entire night – the entire night. Granted you were too drunk to remember much of the details and the morning hit you with one heck of a headache, but all in all, it was worth it ...

Besides, apparently that girl is a camp follower because the next night she was there again, doling out more drinks. This time you didn't hesitate at all, but accepted everything eagerly.

Gotta admit, this job has been the easiest and most fun you've had in what seemed forever. Six months of this would be a breeze.

Noon the next day the caravan arrives back at the old geezer's crumbling estate.

Within two days, you are anxious to be out on the road with a caravan again. Although you fellow guards accept you as an equal comrade after the shared drinks, exploits and nights on the road, for the most part, they spend more time drinking and whoring than training. Even though you wouldn't consider yourself a stalwart example of regular practice, you do take some pride in your skills. They've fed you and kept you alive. A mercenary lives or dies by their skills but even as you watch the people around you, you can see that they have gotten too relaxed. They're far better at boasting than in physical tasks. When you start asking questions, it's clear that those in the worst physical condition are those that have been there the longest.

Olmar, the guard whose worked or the old merchant for almost two years is all flab, heavy gut and from the glimpses you've gotten of his knife and sword, he hasn't bothered to sharpen them for at least a year. According to him, since the Gallino took over the caravans about a year and a half ago, there haven't been any problems with thieves or ambushes. It just doesn't add up to you. In a war-troubled part of the country, what made the old geezer's caravans exempt from even an occasional scuffle? A trained eye watching the group would quickly discern that they weren't in much condition to defend their posts. Yes, on the trip out security is watched but on the return trip, they were prime targets for any well planned attack. They may not be hauling merchandise, but Gallino must be carrying a fortune in gold or whatever else he got from the sales and when you think it through, the latter would be more valuable, easier to escape with and far more liquid in bartering. In fact, you try not to think it too far through because soon it seems like an opportunity too good to pass up ... I mean, it wouldn't take much to bargain with some local mercenaries at that inn and plan an attack that could make you and the group very wealthy ...
154111111111.title: What a night!

choices: Approach Gallino (the son and Caravan master)
Approach the Merchant (who hired you and whose money is endangered)
1541111111112.content:
No, you might bend a few rules, but you'd never outright betray or steal from even a half-honest employer – even if he is a fool. Of course, part of the question is who is more the fool: Gallino for allowing such lax security on the return trip, or the old geezer for assuming that someone else would enforce his rules?

So if you're not going to profit from their foolishness, then you certainly would prefer not to suffer for it by being a prime target for an attack. The right thing to do is to try and get your superiors to take this seriously – it's either that or try to convince your fellow mercenaries of their danger, but considering that they seem to think this job is ideal, that's not overly likely.

So, that leaves trying to give some healthy advice to Gallino or jump ranks and inform the old geezer that his rules aren't being followed.
1541111111112.title: The Chain of Command

choices: Find out more about this "Natin" criminal first
15411111111121.content:
On your way to find Gallino, you circle the big house near an open window. From inside, you hear the voices of two strangers, a male and female. Although they kept their voices low, it peaks your curiosity and you creep near the wall to listen.
"Has it all been arranged?" the woman asks.
"Yes."
"Good, when will it happen?"
"The first night of the return trip," the man replies. "It's our best chance. Melina knows where the caravan always camps that night. She says her friends will help so if all goes well, all the guards will be asleep before the attack."
You tense, your breathing quickening. Traitors among the merchant's own servants?
"But Natin," the young woman protests, "are you sure that we can trust people like ...," she hesitated, as if searching for the right word, "well, like her."
You roll your eyes, would have been nice to have it confirmed, but it seemed only logical that this Melina was one of the women that visited and entertained the guards at night. The female inside sounded rather self-righteous for someone planning a betrayal of their own master. Natin – you'll have to remember that name since it was the best clue for nailing these traitors. You've never heard the name – that you can recall – but then the guards have very little interaction with house servants except for those that brought meals to the barracks. It was too risky to try to sneak look at the two. The name would have to do – besides, it sounded like he was the one running the operations. She may just be a maid who spied on people and gathered information.

"Yes," the man called Natin assured her. "Trust me, they have as much reason to hate him as we do."

Wasn't too hard to conclude that "him" meant the merchant since he was the biggest one to suffer from a raid.

The voices fade and you hear a door close, then silence. You stay crouched by the wall for a moment, considering your options.

The real question now is whether or not you should report this to Gallino. At this point, you didn't have any evidence – just chance eavesdropping – and the man Natin would definitely deny it so it would end up being your word against his. Not ideal for just being hired on a week or so ago. On the other hand, the caravan would probably be heading out soon if plans were already set in motion.
15411111111121.title: Whispered Treason

choices: Sneak into the Main house – your instincts have never failed you before!
Feign ignorance 'n wait for the perfect moment.
154111111111212.content:
"Olmar, do you know a servant in the main house whose name is Natin?" you question as you drop down in a seat beside the old guard.

He peers at you over his mug of ale, his dark eyes bemused, then he burst into loud, rumbling laughter. "How much you been drinkin' already?" he chuckles. "Natin ain't no servant. He's the boss's own flesh and blood."

You stare at the man, stunned. "You mean this guy is family?"

Olmar lifts his mug in a salute. "Youngest son. Come'on, there's only three of them. Not that hard to keep 'em straight."

You groan, rub your eyes and ask, "Okay, so what's the guy like?"

Olmar shrugs. "Quiet guy, somber. Don't know much about him really 'cause he's not the type to come over here. He keeps clear of the barracks and not too keep on mixin' with our type."

Vaguely, you remember some of the comments about him back at the inn, but there wasn't much useful. "I hear he wears a sword, can he use it?"

The old guard shrugged again. "Don't rightly know, but I guess so. Think he takes lessons from some local noble or atleast a fancy warrior employed as a teacher by some noble but don't know who. Certainly never practices over here or asks for pointers from us."

"Do you know of any bad blood between him and his father? Any reason why the guy might hate the boss?"

Olmar squinted at him. "Hate the boss?" He frowned and stopped to think. "Can't think of much. The boy's pretty young still. Except for maybe that scandal last year."

"What happen?"

The man groaned. "Ah, heck, I don't remember. Something about a common girl and Natin being forced to marry her. Or maybe he wanted to marry her and the boss wouldn't have it. All I know was that the girl ended up going missing for about a week and when they found her she was dead."

"And you don't remember if the guy wanted to marry or was trying to get out of it?" you demand. "Good grief, it makes a big difference. If he didn't want to marry her then he might have killed her to settle the issue, or paid someone else to take her out."

"Does it really matter?" Olmar scoffed in his gruff voice. "These nobles have their own ways in this place. It don't matter what they do – murder or steal or whatever – cause they got money and that's all the law cares about in this place." He levels his black eyes on you. "Trust me, best to stick to our own business and just leave them to deal with their own."

He did have a point. At least now you're glad you didn't rush it and tell Gallino. Accusing a servant was one thing, but accusing the boss's son of treachery without proof is something else entirely. So, that left you with two options. Do you get proof to nail the guy, or do you go along with it and stick to your job by trying to protect the caravan from attack as best as you can without implementing the snake? With only tonight to gather proof, you'll be working blind and hope you get lucky – not to mention it will probably require sneaking into the big house and breaking who knows how many rules in your contract. If you wait until after the return of the caravan you will have more time to work, but you're not overly sure of your ability to keep an entire caravan safe without somebody else on your side. Either way, the odds were against you, but then again, that's usually when you are at your best ...

Besides the old geezer seemed a decent guy and it made you sick to think of his own son betraying him like this. Regardless of Olmar's warnings, you aren't about to let him get away with it.
154111111111212.title: Bad Blood

choices: Keep the pressure on and offer her a deal if she helps nail Natin
Promise nothing and rely on your charms to win her cooperation
1541111111112121.content:
Sneaking into the main house was simple. Most of the guards that did actually patrol areas were mostly concerned with the security of the outer walls and crumbling as they were, that alone was one heck of a job. Because the big house was originally a military keep, there weren't too many servant entrances, but the two or three that had been adapted to be worker entrances weren't guarded.

Inside, only torches lighting intersections had been left burning so shadows cloaked most of the corridors.

You creep down through the darkness, one hand stretched out along the wall in front of you and your other hand on the knife at your belt. Although you left the rest of your weapons in the barracks, the one knife should be enough for whatever you come up against. Secrecy was most important since getting caught in this act would mean a broken contract – jail.

It just would be nice if you knew where to start.

You steal through the maze of hallways, turning right here and left there, but always keeping a visual map of your course so you can find your way back.

As you chance another right turn, you peer down the new corridor and catch a glimpse of movement – a dark figure backing silently out of a doorway. You press yourself tight against the wall at your back but the person doesn't notice you. The stranger looks far more intent on shutting the door silently before moving on. You see your chance and slip forward, pulling your knife free as you near the person. Just as the figure pulls the wooden door flush with the wall and turn, you slip behind them, covering the person's mouth with one hand and bringing your knife up to their throat.

The stranger jerks, startled, and a muffled whimper escapes your hand. You pull the person deeper into the shadows and hiss, "Who are you and what are you doing here?"

In the darkness, you see the whites of the person's startled eyes as he or she struggles to see you. You feel the person's slim form twist and slender fingers grip the arm holding the knife. The soft scent of jasmine only confirms the gender of the intruder.

You feel her struggling to speak and you ease your hand an inch away from her mouth.

"I live here," she gasped.

"Then why are you sneaking around at night while everyone is asleep. What were you doing?"

She twists against your grip, hissing defiantly, "I don't have to tell you anything. Who in the world are you, anyway?"

"I'm a guard," you retort, "so don't mess with me. What were you doing?"

"Guards aren't allowed in here – especially not at night," she scoffed.

You pull her tighter against you and whisper in her ear, "I'm asking the questions. Or would you rather explain your actions to the boss?"

She leaned her head back and eyed you, letting out a short laugh. "You don't scare me," she taunted. "Go ahead and wake the whole household. You have far more to lose than I do."

You tense. That voice. As you manage to place it, a grin spreads across your face. "Really? And what if I tell him that you are part of a conspiracy to betray him?"

"I don't know what you're talking about."

Annoyed at her arrogance, you turn and pin her to the wall so you can see her face. "Don't play innocent with me," you growl. "The game's up. I heard your little conversation with Natin this afternoon – the one where you were discussing the planned attack on the caravan."

The woman's skin paled slightly as her eyes widened. Her breathing came hard as she stared back at you. Even in the darkness, you can see her smooth complexion and a tense beauty.

It seems luck is definitely on your side. With the right persuasion, this young woman might give you all the evidence you need to trap that snake of a son.

She may not be afraid of being found wandering around in the dark, but she was scared now, knowing that you knew about the conspiracy. You had the upper hand, but she seemed a bit of a spitfire so you'd better choose well how you use it.
1541111111112121.title: Renegade Private Eye

choices: Follow the girl into the room
15411111111121211.content:
"I'm willing to offer you a deal so please just hear me out." Keeping a strong grip on the girl you meet her curious stare. "I could go to the boss with this information any time, and I doubt that it will go well for you – whoever you are."

"Galen won't believe you," she whispered.

"Are you so sure about that?"

She looked away. "He has a blind trust in his sons. You need a lot more proof than your word to convince him that either of them are working against him. You'd probably end up being the one in prison just for hinting at such."

"And frankly, that's why I haven't done anything yet," you admit, "because I much prefer some sort of evidence to back me, but let me assure you of one thing – if it comes down to it, I'm willing to go in there with just what I have now."

Her eyes widened as she stared at you. "I just said you'd end up in prison."

You eyed her skeptically, "As if you care about what happens to a stranger like me?" you muse. "But yes, I would do it rather than remain silent. Call it a personal issue, but I the boss seems a decent guy and I can't stand by and watch his own son betray him – not if I can help it."

Her eyes search yours as if not convinced or just surprised by your insistence, but you don't have anything to hide there.

"Now," you continue, "I don't know how you got wrapped up in all of this, but I'm willing to give you the benefit of the doubt and give you a choice. Help me get the evidence I need and I'll convince the boss that you're clean, or I'll let you walk away now and I'll get the evidence on my own to take him down and you down with him."

Once you see her expression deepen in thought, you back away, giving her enough room to run if she decides. However, she doesn't move for a long moment, but studies you through the darkness.

"Do you real value the loyalty between father and son so much?"

You nod.

She narrows her eyes. "How can I trust that you're being honest with me?"

You give an open shrug. "I'm risking my job by even being here and talking to you. If I didn't care what happens, then I would have gone straight to Gallino or done nothing at all."

She stiffened. "Do you trust Gallino?"

"The boss has entrusted the caravan to Gallino so since this concerns the caravan, it only makes sense to talk to him first."

"But what about the loyalty between father and son? Why look after Galen?"

"The older merchant is the one who hired me, and is the one paying me, so my loyalty is to him first."

She chewed on her lip as she considered, then nodded. "Follow me, I know a place where we can talk."

You hesitate, but decide to follow her since you gave her the option of running and she didn't.

She leads you down the dark hallway and then stops to knock on a door.

You tense as you hear a muffled, sleepy voice call out, "Who is it?"

The girl lifts an open hand, gesturing you to be patient, then answers the voice. "It's Salyna. We need to talk."

You hear the shuffle of footsteps and the door opens. "This had better be important," the man inside mutters.

Your hand clenches around your knife as you recognize the voice. It's the same as you heard earlier that day – Natin.
15411111111121211.title: Negotiations

choices: Quit while you're ahead and run like hell!
Heck with the consequences and continue the interrogation/seduction ...
15411111111121212.content:
Easing up a bit, you take a deep breath, then whisper, "Is there someplace we can go to talk?"

She studies you for a long moment before nodding. "Yes, I guess we should talk." Hesitating, she peers down the corridor and chews on her bottom lip.

Impatient, you suggest, "The simplest would just be your quarters unless you share a room with another maid or something."

She sighs. "Okay, follow me."

You let her head for the servant wing but stay close enough to grab her if she tries to run. As you pass beneath the rare torches, you note the long braid of dark hair down the young woman's back, almost lost in the simple, dark skirt and tunic. With that dark of hair and that figure, she probably had gypsy blood in her. That was pretty common in that area although most pure-blood gypsies had left years ago because of the wars and all the different bands of fighters wandering the countryside.

She soon turns to a door and glances back at you as she opens it and allows you to enter first. With your knife still out, you enter cautiously, keeping one eye on her.

The room is empty – a simple maid's room with a narrow bed and a trunk pushed against the wall. A wooden table with a wash basin and polished silver mirror. A small, solitary candle sat beside the basin and the young woman picked it up and lit it from the torch in the hallway, then returned and closed the door. With the candle in her hands, you catch the glint of dark green in her eyes, highlighted with golden reflections of the flame.

Confident that the room is secure, you slip the knife back into the sheath. "I apologize for the rough introduction back there, but I am supposed to help keep this place secure and I take my job seriously."

She raised one eyebrow. "Yet you seem to pick and choose since I know mercenaries aren't allowed in here – especially at night. Who are you?"

You lift your head and offer a casual smile, giving your name. Taking a few steps toward her, meeting her stare with an easy, roaming study of her face and figure. "So why would a pretty little thing like you be involved in such deceit?"

She pursed her lips, glancing away. "Things are not always what they seem."

You tilt your head to catch her gaze again. "Are you speaking of your beauty, or of the conversation? From where I stand, they both seem pretty obvious to me."

Peering at you from the corner of her eyes, she asks, "Have you told anyone what you heard?"

"Do you think I shouldn't?"

She sighed. "I know it sounded bad, but it really isn't what you think."

Once you are within an arm's reach, you lower your voice and ask softly, "Are you in love with Natin?"

Startled by the question, she lifts her face full into view. "What do you mean by that?"

Shrugging, you mutter, "Well, many women have done more for a man they think they love, so it would explain how you got involved."

She lifts her chin arrogantly. "Fine," she declares, "I love him, but what why should you care?"

You raise one eyebrow skeptically. "That didn't sound too convincing. Is it because he doesn't really care for you? Guys like him tend to use girls more than love them back."

"Guys like him?" she scoffs, glaring at you. "You don't know anything about Natin."

You move in a step closer, using your height to your advantage since her eyes reaching your chin-level. "I do know that any son who would betray his father behind his back doesn't deserve the love of someone as lovely and spirited as you."

Lifting her head higher to meet your gaze, you can tell that she's shaken by your closeness, but she doesn't back down. "Are you trying to hint that you might be more deserving?"

Giving her one of your disarming grins you mumble, "Maybe. Certainly sounds like a good place to start."

A faint blush colors her cheeks and she looks away, shielding the candle flame.

Another step closer. "Has he ever kissed you?"

The blush deepens and she turns on you sharply. "No, how can you-"

Pushing the candle aside, you pull her to you, wrapping one arm around her tense waist and claim her lips with your own, cutting off her protest and her breath. She struggles against you, pushing at you with her free hand, but is no match for your strength. Her other hand clenches around the candle, the light flickering and tossing shadows in the dark room, but your own hand keeps the arm far away. The last thing you want is to be singed by maidenly outrage. Shifting closer, you feel her struggles fade, unmistakable submission evident in her slight lean against you. You deepen the kiss to erase all lingering hesitation on her part, then, once you are sure of her returned desire, you pull back, your body tense with its own demands.

The young woman sucks in a breath of air, her body heaving against your and her face flushed.

"What's your name?" you whisper, kissing the corner of her lips.

"Salyna," she breathes, her voice shaking.

"Salyna," you purr, drawing out the name in a seductive tone that few women – especially young women – have ever been able to resist. "And do you still love Natin?"

She hesitates but you slide your hand up her back, pressing her to you and caressing with your fingers to bring her mind back to focusing on you.

"Yes," she groans.

Your fingers tighten, pressing against her back and you trail kisses to her ear, but fight to keep anger out of your voice as you hiss, "Why?"

"He's my brother."
15411111111121212.title: A Bit of Persuassion can go too far ...

choices: Prefer to keep it between those actually involved
15411111111122.content:
"The master cannot be disturbed," protested a withered old servant. "He is a very busy man. May I ask what this is about?"

"I wish to speak to him about the security on the caravan," you explain. "I guess it's not urgent, but I just had a few questions about the rules."

The white-haired man shrugs. "Master Gallino is the one responsible for the caravan. You may take the matter up with him. He has much more time available than his father since the caravan is –for the most part- his only major duty."

You frown. "Like I said, it's not urgent. Just let the master know that I wish to see him when he has time." You turn and head back to the barracks.

So Gallino is only really working when he's running the caravan? He didn't seem the lazy type but yet you haven't seen him around the estate so how did he pass the time between trips? Not that you knew much about the man since he kept to himself on the road except to keep order and managing the handling and selling of merchandise. Seems a somber, quiet type that's always stressed underneath. You've never seen him loosen up so it's possible that when he's not on a caravan he goes elsewhere to kick-back.

Speaking of which, that was another thing that didn't seem overly logical. Why did he seem so stressed if he only managed the caravans? If it was the strain of the responsibility, why would he be so lax on the security.

"I heard you were looking for my father," a male voice interrupts your thoughts.

You turn to find a young man no more than twenty, with brown eyes and sandy-colored hair. He's a stranger to you, but you had heard that there was a younger brother in the merchant's family so you conclude that this must be him. A relatively skinny lad but a determined seriousness in his brown eyes.

"My name is Natin," the young man explains, "and I was wondering what business you wanted to discuss with my father."
15411111111122.title: The Younger Son

154111111112.content:
Maybe turning the drink down hadn't been the best choice. As soon as you say no, the girl pouts and the entire group of girls and mercenaries all gang up to pressure you into drinking. Determined to stick to your word but not willing to start a fight by pointing out that they shouldn't be drinking either, you eventually get up and leave the main campfire, muttering something about going to check on the wagons. This is the first caravan trip for you and the last thing you need is to make a big scene. So far, the others have been pretty accepting and you want to keep it that way if you can.

The night air is cool and you pull your cloak tighter against the wind. Glancing about the camp you sigh. Away from the boisterous group at the campfire, the rest of the area seems deserted. You had expected at least a few guards to still be walking the perimeter. As it was, the whole area around the wagons lay silent and vulnerable. It's a good thing the merchandise had all been sold, but even then it seemed odd that no one cared about the value of the wagons themselves and you could have sworn that when Gallino came back to wagons that afternoon, after dealing with selling/delivering the goods, he'd brought a few wooden crates back. Maybe they hadn't sold, or maybe part of the business included trading for something that would be valuable back in Hewor. You didn't really know all that much about the details of how merchants operate, but at the very least, Gallino must have a valuable return in some form stashed somewhere. From the way the old geezer had acted the day you signed on, the guy seemed awfully concerned about security and the safety of his family, yet Gallino – the one in the most danger if there was an attack – didn't seem worried.

You shrug, staring at one of the wagons. Maybe whatever was in those crates wasn't valuable at all. Could be something simple, like food stuff or something. Out of curiousity, you glance around, then wander over to the nearest wagon.

"It's only reasonable," you rationalize, "it's best to know what you're guarding, right?" Yet when you reach the wagon, you hesitate – your hand on the oiled tarp.
154111111112.title: Lonely Duty

15411111112.content:
When your employer hears of your actions, you discover that he certainly was not bluffing. Even in a city where the law authorities rarely bother with outright murder right outside their own door, a merchant with money can be a powerful enemy. You are promptly arrested and thrown into prison without a trial in a dark back cell to wait until the end of your sentence, or until they forget to feed you too long...

... whichever comes first.
15411111112.title: Broken Contract

"I am actually the lost son of a displaced nobleman."

The merchant narrowed his gray-blue eyes at you. "Are you trying to claim literacy?"

You scoop up the parchment and read the first line in flawless articulation.

The potential employer leans back, raises his eyebrows and views you with a renewed respect. "And where would someone like you learn such?"

You lift you head as you reply:
1541111112.title: Enter the EDUCATED Mercenary

choices: "It pays the bills and for someone like me, that important."
"I agree. This war has drug on too long."
15411111121.content:
"As a child, my earliest memories were of a lone child in the streets of a small town. There was a monastery in the town and one of the monks took pity on me. He brought me into the monastery to educate in hopes of giving me a brighter future. Although those higher up frowned on the action – particularly because as you see, I'm only half human - , they didn't stop the monk and most of the brethren accepted me warmly."

"Then may I ask how you became a mercenary? Were you rebellious?"

You shake your head. "No, I loved them like a family, but when I was a young man, the town was cruelly attacked under the cover of darkness and the buildings razed to the ground. I survived because the monks hid me in the catacombs where there dead were buried. There was just enough moisture to keep the fire away, but I was the only survivor. After that night, I swore to track down the people responsible for the attack, but the trail turned cold after a month or so and I knew that I would need far more training and skills if I was to succeed. With no money or any one who knew me, mercenary training and work was how I kept alive."

The merchant stroked his bearded chin. "What is your name?"

After you gave it, the man replied, "I am Galen Tarish. You are an interesting man with a dark past, I see." Galen grinned. "I like you." He gestured to the contract. "Please, feel free to study it and ask any questions you wish." He waved to his servant to escort Taz out, leaving you and the merchant alone in the room.

For the most part, the contract was simply verbatim of what Galen had said. You eye him. "What's the merchandise you trade?"

Galen shrugged. "Standard stuff – lots of quality fabric, including the best silk on the market - prime ale and wine, and spices with a few medicinal herbs."

You raise one quizzical eyebrow. "So you don't cater to the war?"

Galen grimaced. "I want nothing to do with that type of people. It's because of these idiots that I have to waste so much money on guards! All the cut-throats brought in by the war and paid to wander the countryside are half thieves and when they're bored, they seem to think it's fun to lurk around my estates, steal from my caravans and would probably love to demand ransom on one of my children. They should have concluded this years ago and I doubt even the nobility has a clue what they are fighting about. Lord Rynav and Lady Mesdea are just dragging it out. They're both wasteful, bloody fools!"

Folding your arms, you study the man. "At the inn, I overheard someone refer to the Lady Mesdea as a Witch Queen."

Galen pounds a fist on the wooden desk and declares, "Rubbish! She has no more royal blood than I have dwarven. Hewor hasn't had, needed or wanted a monarch for over two hundred years and that goes for all the surrounding towns as well. The royal line died and is best left buried."

You nod, a slight smile edging your lips. The 'old geezer' has quite a bit of back bone.

Galen meets your gaze and leans back again in his chair, steepling his fingers. "You seem the cunning and intelligent type so I wonder. What is your opinion of the war?"
15411111121.title: Some dark background & quest

choices: Strip him and turn him loose.
154111111212.content:
"Well, I do agree the war has gone on for far too long. On the other hand, it does allow me to eat and live in some small degree of comfort. But, the bottom line is this... If the war doesn't end soon, there will be no food except whatever comes in from outside."

I continued, "The peasants haven't been able to tend their crops, if they were lucky enough to plant at all. Even if they did plant, most of the fields have been trampled into ruin by these fools playing at war. And with all the men old enough to father children getting killed off, soon enough, there won't be any peasants left to plant crops anyhow! But, that's only my opinion Galen."

He looked thoughtfully at me for several long seconds. "I could only wish those two fools could have an adviser such as yourself. More, I could wish they would have the sense to listen to such an adviser! Well, come then. You've a job for the time being."

We left the inn. As we began to walk down the street, I heard the faint scrape of a blade being drawn. I spun around, thankful I had inherited the ability of being able to see the red glow of a warm body in the dark from my mother's people. It was an ability elves possessed, but only sometimes passed to those with half-blood. I didn't speak of it, but it had saved my life more than once!

I stepped to my left, stabbing right with my sword as I did so. The bandit died with a soft gurgle as my blade took him in the throat. A side-step took me out of the other assailant's path. I clubbed him in the back of his head as he stepped past me. He fell heavily, stunned or unconscious. "Galen, we have company. Two of them. One is dead, the other down. Shall I bring him so he can be questioned?"
154111111212.title: A fine start

1541111112121.content:
I stripped the bandit of all his weapons before dragging him down the street. Galen stopped when we drew abreast of a lit window. "Now, let's take a look at this fine fellow."

I drew him closer to the light. Galen gasped, "By all that's holy! This thug wears the colors of the Lady Mesdea! He's one of her henchmen. Did you check the other man for papers?"

"All he had were his weapons and this," I said holding up a fat purse.

"Drag him down the alley. Strip him of everything but his life and leave him. I don't know what this is about, but I know for certain it doesn't bode well for me or mine."

I stepped out of the alley moments later carrying the man's clothing, weapons and purse. "We'll drop the clothes in the charity box in front of Tyr's Temple. You may do as you wish with his weapons and the contents of both purses. If you wish, I will tear up our contract. The Lady is said to have a long reach and I'll not wish to add another to her list of those who have crossed her."

"No. I think I'll stay in your employ. At least for the time being. I think I should be able to make some good coin out of this, if you give rewards like this," I said as I bounced the purses in my palm.
1541111112121.title: Rewards

choices: Definitely (deals like this are once in a lifetime!)
I'll help, but the special treatment may hinder
15411111121211.content:
Galen smiles. "Yes, I do indeed favor you and need more men like you on my side. I think you would be wasted simply as a guard and am willing to offer you a deal." He glances around as you both walk, checking for people close enough to overhear your conversation, but decides it's safe as he continues. "As you see by that reckless ambush, I need someone I can trust to help protect my lands, family and business from these fools. I think they have bribed and seduced information from my servants and workers. Now they have moved to direct attacks in daylight no less! Sabotage is the next step and only an idiot would sit back and wait for them. They'll ruin me if they can." He grimaces. "They've been working on it for years, but," he adds with a smug grin, "I always outwit them in the end."

"And what's the deal?" you press, intent on the details and not just the theories. Ideals and abstracts don't make money and they certainly don't win fights. Usually they just make you an easy target.

"I will give you triple the regular pay and you will have access to the main house and a private room in the servant quarters. You will report only to me." His eyes grow serious as he studies you. "I want you to gather info on the plans of my enemies and find out who is loyal to me and who is out to destroy me."
15411111121211.title: A special deal

choices: I move into the guard barracks.
154111111212112.content:
"I'll take the job. I'm not too sure about the special status though. It will be the news of your household before I've spent a night under your roof. That will make the servants less likely to talk to me."

We sat in silence for some moments before I said, "Let your servants know you've hired me to work up the defenses of the house. This will give me a reason to be in the house, poking my nose into odd corners. I'll actually figure out where your home is vulnerable and what you can do about it. In the meantime, the servants will soon begin to ignore me, allowing me to overhear their conversation or see them at work with their daily activities."

"Very well, I can do this," Galen said.

"Are any of the servants younger girls?" I asked. "Those who have changed or began to change into women, but are not yet settled with a man?"

"Aye. There are several like that."

"Good. Such find me exotic enough to be interested in my charms." I held up a hand to forestall the protest forming on Galen's lips. "I am not seeking to foster myself into such a maid's bed. But, one who thinks she might bed me, thus gaining bragging rights among the others, will be much looser with her tongue. There will, of course, be several such girls. There always are." I said with a sigh.

Galen scowled, but finally said, "Aye, that's probably true enough. Do what you must. Mind my daughter is NOT among them. She is young enough to be entranced by your appearance."

"Be sure to make her known to me that I do not, then."

Galen nodded. He pulled a washed leather purse from a pocket and tossed it to me. "Your word is your bond. Here is your first month's pay, up front as a good-will gesture on my part."

I handed it back. "Keep it until the end of the month. Anything you do which is different where I am concerned will attract attention to me, making my job all the harder. With the two pouches I've already collected tonight, I have plenty to tide me over until payday."
154111111212112.title: The Plan

choices: An unseen archer fires an arrow into the house...
1541111112121121.content:
It was getting late by the time we reached Galen's home. We had worked out the beginnings of our plan where I would be introduced to the household the next morning. I would meet the captain of the guards, the chamberlain, the mistress of servants and Galen would point out his sons and daughter to me. My job was to check out the defenses of the home and yards, then make recommendations as to how best to secure them against attack. I was to have the run of the house during the day, but at night, I was supposed to have the same restrictions as any other mercenary. Only Galen and I knew differently.

I returned to my inn, gathered my things and went back to Galen's. I entered by way of the main gate before it was closed for the night. The corporal of the guard escorted me to the barracks. He told me he had heard I would be arriving late, but he hoped I would understand if he posted a guard until I could be better identified. I told him I did understand and if he wanted, to spare his guards a partial nights sleep, i would be willing to allow him to lock me in a cell until morning.

He grinned and said, "Ah, the lot of a soldier is to go sleepless so others may sleep sound, to go hungry so others may eat and to die if need be so others may live."

I smiled back and said. "As a rule, I have found it much better to make the enemy die for his god rather than dying for mine." He laughed aloud at this and pointed the way to a small room at the bottom of some stairs.

"You may take your gear with you." He signaled to two privates and they came forward. "These are privates Conn and Gilsepth. They shall watch over your sleep the first part of the evening. Others will relieve them throughout the night until time for morning chow. At that time, we shall go to our dining area and make sure you are fed the best gruel money can buy. Who knows, perhaps you may have luck and actually find some meat within it."

I entered the room, unrolled my blankets and went immediately to sleep. I woke with each changing of the guard and pretended sleep when two men entered my room around two of the clock. They merely looked around and disturbed nothing, so I let them live when they left. I was up and ready before the sun had risen in the sky. The corporal of the guard came back and collected me. He handed me a key to fit the lock on the door, which I closed and locked. We went to breakfast and ate the gruel he had spoken of and dined on hard rolls which he hadn't mentioned. Then, we were off to the main house to meet the captain of the guard and Galen.
1541111112121121.title: I move into the guard barracks.

Start with the outside of the house.
15411111121211211.content:
I was introduced to the captain of the guard, a swarthy looking man of about 40. He was lean and tall with dark hair and brooding eyes. He also had several scars on his arms and one small gash down the side of his cheek. He was one I would not like to have to engage in a sword fight. He appeared to be wearing a bastard sword on his right side and a fighting dirk on his left. That told me none of my usual training would be effective against him since the moves would all be backward.

I ducked my head, "Good morn to you, Galen. I am prepared to begin my work as soon as you wish."

You have broken fast, have you not?" he asked gruffly. At my nod, he said, "Come along then. This is the captain of the guard here. Dan'l Tremont." Galen led the way down a narrow hallway which opened into a bigger room. This my housekeeper, Elaine Halfblood. My Majordomo is Sal Tallfellow. The housekeeper is in charge of all the females working here. The majordomo is in charge of everyone else. And, this is my daughter, Saline Moongift."

Looking at her, I could see where the old man wouldn't want her bedded by anyone before she married. She had a regal bearing to her, standing almost as tall as my own 5' 8". She could have weighed no more than 5 stone (100 pounds) and had a beautiful glow about her. Her reddish hair and creamy complexion were enough to seduce any man. She also possessed the most penetrating green eyes I had ever seen. Her breasts were full, but not overly huge. Her waist was small and her hips were just right on her, neither too big nor too small. I would have to watch myself around her!

Galen explained my duties and said, "He'll be poking his nose into every crack and crevice of the house. If he asks you a question, answer it to the best of your ability. Otherwise, ignore him. He will only be in the house during the day. Any questions?" he asked. Getting no response, he said, "Good! Back to work then." Galen led the way back to the little room where we had first been. "You know what to do. Find out what you must and report back to me. Good luck," he said, offering his hand. I shook it and he nodded at my firm grasp.
15411111121211211.title: So far, so good.

choices: Nah, I'd rather buy the info without the commitment.
15411111122.content:
"I am the son of a human lord and an elven priestess. However, my father's family could never accept the marriage and claimed it a farce and betrayal. When I was born, I was condemned by the superstitious as a changeling or a demon child, saying that no child of mixed blood can claim a soul.

"The household and servants of the estate rebelled and threatened to abandon my father – both hating and fearing me even as an infant – so to keep peace, my father sent me and my mother away. I never knew my father but my mother told me stories of him and showed me his letters. He sent gold secretly to provide for us and even a tutor to educate me. Unfortunately, not long after I became an adolescent, the messages and gold stopped without warning. My mother sank into depression and when I offered to search out my father's fate, she refused to tell me his name or house in fear that his family would find me and kill me.

You look away, troubled by the memories of your beautiful mother wasting away in grief and silence. "Eventually I couldn’t take it any more and I left to make my way on my own."

The merchant studies you skeptically. "Your story is intriguing, but any man with a bit of learning and an active imagination could concoct such a story to dupe any fool. With no names, dates or house to confirm your claims, it's possible that you are lying or even that you have been lied to."

You stiffen, fist tight at your sides. "I was not lied to," you declare. "I said I don't know his name or family, but I do have proof."

The man lifted an eyebrow. "Really?"

You pull on the thin, metal chain around your neck, feeling the heavy man's ring slip free of the neck of your tunic. Holding it out for the merchant to see, you eye the gold band, thickly encrusted with small diamonds and a large sapphire.

Impressed, the merchant stands and asks, "May I inspect your relic?"

You nod, only slightly nervous. You never showed the heirloom to anyone, cautious about your enemies finding you before you can identify them, but if you were going to commit to six months of working for this guy, you'd prefer it an open deal on both sides. Besides, as a merchant, he might even know something helpful.

The man studied the ring for a long moment, stroking his chin. "There is a crest here – or rather the hint of one," the merchant informs you.

"Where?" you demand, eager for any information.

"The pattern of the diamonds," he explains, "they are set in a star constellation, I'm sure of it."

"And do you know what noble house used that constellation?"

The man sighed. "It has been decades since such have been used as crests. Most have been dropped to adopt modern styles. I'd have to research it more to know." He eyes you shrewdly. "But time for such research and tracing can get pricey. Perhaps we can make a deal. You work for me and I will track this ring for you."
15411111122.title: Exiled Nobility

choices: Stick to a rule of "stay out of family battles" – particularly sibling r
Give her the benefit of the doubt (beauty or 1st come 1st served etc)
154111111221.content:
Although you're not sure how much of your story the Merchant believes, he introduces himself as Galen Tarish and signs you on as a house guard. Your pay remains the same, but after the glare that Taz gives you as he's dismissed to the barracks, you decide that it's probably best. You hadn't intended the story of your past to come out this soon, but you would be a fool to pass up a chance to find out who and where your father is. Taz didn't look too impressed by your claims and you doubted that the other mercenaries in Galen's employ would accept you as one of them now. You sigh. And so the cycle begins again. Getting others to accept my half race status was one thing and whenever my past comes up, it only isolates me further – you'd think I'd be used to it by now – but just once it would be nice to be viewed by who I am and not my ancestry. For all it's promises and possibilities, so far it's only produced more enemies and complications.

As the singular house guard, you have a private room in the main house and your duties mainly consist with maintaining the security of the main house at night, dealing with would-be intruders, following up on suspicious activities, breaking up any domestic fights if they turn violent and reporting rule-breaking to Galen. All in all, it seemed pretty straightforward – that is until you walk the grounds around the house and realize all the shadowed arbors, the three servant entries that added on in the most isolated corners and the low, first-floor windows that had been carved into the original garrison design. Window shutters and doors had no bolts or beams to keep them closed except for the main front door and that one not only looked like it hadn't been used in years, but when you handle it, you discover that it's half rotten. It wouldn't hold up against two strong kicks from a determined attacker.

On the inside, the hallways twist and turn then end abruptly with lots of isolated branches and when you ask, you discover that to cut back on costs, only torches at intersections were left burning at night. That left major sections of shadows for people to hide and sneak through the innards of the building. With just yourself, it looked like a serious all-nighter.

Once you are thoroughly discouraged by the security you are responsible for, you are summoned to meet the house servants. More than two-third of the men looked like they had served the estate when Galen was a mewling infant. On the other hand, most of the maids looked in their twenties or lower with relatively slim figures and pretty faces. The only two women who looked matronly were the head cook and the head housekeeper and they seemed ill-impressed with their young helpers. Even as you enter the room where they are assembled, you can hear the two women bellowing reprimands at their underlings. The girls, although pretty, had no qualms about laughing and yelling back at their superiors and frankly anyone who questioned them. Although they seem to have the advantage of numbers and graphic name calling over their elders, you discover after about three or four cat-fights later, that the girls were just as vicious and competitive against each other than authority figures – apparently more so. The main dispute among them seemed to be a select, coveted group of mercenaries. It seemed odd to you since you were used to maids like that fighting over the sons of the boss but since you haven't actually seen or met either of Galen two sons yet, you supposed that it might be that they were out of shape, overweight or otherwise unappealing to females.

It isn't hard to guess that most of your "would-be" night intruders will probably be mercenaries from the barracks trying to make or keep night appointments with the maids. You figure you should probably clarify with Galen whether or not he considered moon-light trysts in the gardens as a threat to the main house. You're also not sure when you will be able to get some sleep during the day without regular interruptions demanding that he break up more catfights. By the time you complete your review of your duties and shuffle back to your room, you already feel exhausted and sleep-deprived, and thinking about your first night on the job beginning in a couple hours did not help. However, the thought of just being able to lay down on a real bed kept your feet moving until you open your bedroom door and look up to see a beautiful, dark-haired young woman sitting on your bed.

You freeze, looking the stranger over – her slender curves covered in a red-silk dress – and the waves of black hair draped over one lifted shoulder. Troubled, dark green eyes studied you and you notice a touch of fear – not enough to noticed by the casual person, but as a fighter, fear is something you learn to pick up on.

"I need your help," the woman announced, her voice shaking a bit.

Lifting one eyebrow, you ask, "Do you usually intrude on stranger's private space, or only when you want to look desperate? I know the damsel in distress technique so I suggest you have a real convincing story to go with it because I don't favor people who sneak into my bedroom – especially when I don't know them."

She lifted her head somewhat defiantly. "I am Galen's daughter, Salyna Tarish."

Ah, you recall from earlier descriptions, the babe. With one more appraising glance, you decide the reference justified. "So, what help do you need from me?"

"My brother is a crook," the young woman declared. "I want you to help me stop him or at least prove what he is to my father."
